metadata.title: Preparation of a shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst and its application for benzene alkylation with ethylene

(%) 88.46 86.71 86.71 88.33 X/EB (10−6) 580 1100 1030 640 norm. m-DEB (%) 55.7 54.1 39.2 49.2 norm. p-DEB (%) 41.7 43.4 60.1 49.8 norm. o-DEB (%) 2.6 2.5 0.7 1.0 Preparation of a shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst and its application for benzene alkylation with ethylene Zhenhao Shen a b Chongwei Ma c Junlin He b Darui Wang b Hongmin Sun b Zhirong Zhu a ⁎ Weimin Yang b c ⁎⁎ a College of Chemical Science and Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, 200092, PR China College of Chemical Science and Engineering Tongji University Shanghai 200092 PR China b Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Sinopec, Shanghai, 201208, PR China Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology Sinopec Shanghai 201208 PR China c School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200237, PR China School of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Sinopec, Shanghai, 201208, PR China. Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology Sinopec Shanghai 201208 PR China Graphical abstract A kind of shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst is prepared by re-crystallization method, from a shaped mixture of ZSM-5 zeolite and pure silica source as a binder. According to the characterization results, it is found that the silica shell, surrounding the ZSM-5 core in the shaped mixture, can be converted into ZSM-5 zeolite phase under the hydrothermal conditions with vapor-solid phase method. In this way, the catalyst with core-shell zeolite structure is consequently formed. The prepared binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst has more micro-pores than the ordinary shaped zeolite with a binder. In addition, its acidity is weakened because of the migration of framework aluminum towards the outer shell layer of ZSM-5 crystals. When applied to the vapor-phase benzene alkylation with ethylene, this catalyst shows an enhanced stability and selectivity compared to the ordinary shaped catalyst. Specially, xylene, a critical by-product formed by side reactions, is greatly suppressed over the shaped core-shell structured binder-free catalyst. In view of its good mechanical strength as well as its extended lifetime, the shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst will be valuable in the practical industrial ethylbenzene production. Keywords Shaped core-shell binder-free ZSM-5 Acidity Benzene alkylation with ethylene Ethylbenzene Selectivity Stability 1 Introduction Ethylbenzene (EB) is an important bulk chemical intermediate, whose global production capacity is nearly 40 million metric ton in 2017. Over 90% of EB is consumed to produce styrene monomer (SM) via dehydrogenation. With the increasing demand of styrene-containing polymers, the demand of EB is sharply increasing [1]. On the other hand, EB is one of the largest volume derivatives of benzene. It is mainly produced by benzene alkylation with ethylene. Due to corrosion and pollution problems, AlCl3 catalyzed liquid-phase process [2], firstly commercialized in 1930s, was gradually substituted by the non-corrosive and non-polluting zeolite catalyzed processes since 1980s [3,4]. ZSM-5 catalyzed Vapor-Phase Process, processing about 30% of the global EB capacity, is of the same importance as the newly developed Liquid-Phase Process. Vapor-Phase Process possesses high ethylene space velocity and can be easily operated. Especially, it is considered to be more efficient than Liquid-Phase Process when using dilute ethylene sources, e.g. FCC (Fluid Catalytic Cracking) or DCC (Deep Catalytic Cracking) off-gas, because ZSM-5 is less sensitive to the impurities in feedstock [5,6]. However, due to the relatively higher reaction temperature, xylene, residues and other undesired by-products are formed by complicated side reactions. The selectivity and cycle length of the catalyst are accordingly suppressed [7–9]. Xylene is one of the most important by-products, which can be seen as an index to measure the selectivity of benzene/ethylene alkylation process. Because the boiling point of xylene is very close to that of EB, it is difficult to fractionate it from EB. As a result, it will affect the purity of EB and SM products. It is believed that most part of xylene is generated via the side reactions, e.g. EB isomerization, on the strong acid sites of catalysts. Moreover, rising reaction temperature can also accelerate the formation of xylene [10,11]. Therefore, for the alkylation catalyst, it is critical to enhance the selectivity by acidity adjustment as well as to enhance the activity at a lower reaction temperature, which is commonly difficult to realize simultaneously. ZSM-5 (IZA code: MFI), firstly developed by Mobil, is one of the most important zeolites in petrochemical industry. There are two types of 10-MR channels in the structure of ZSM-5, including the straight elliptical pore system (0.53 nm × 0.56 nm) along the (010) axis and the zigzag circular pore system (0.51 nm × 0.55 nm) along the (100) axis [12,13]. Because of its unique 3D pore structure and adjustable acidic properties, ZSM-5 is widely used in petrochemical processes such as FCC, shape selective disproportionation of xylene, benzene alkylation, methanol conversion processes, olefins catalytic cracking (OCC) [1,14–18], etc. ZSM-5 powder must be prepared into shaped forms, such as extrudates, pellets, granules, etc. to obtain a satisfying mechanical strength in industrial applications. Silica, alumina and clay are usually used as binders in catalyst shaping [19]. Because the inert binders with a content of 10–50% may dilute active sites and block the pores of zeolites, they often make the properties of shaped catalysts deviate from their original zeolite powders [20]. The dilution effect by binders drives the framework Al atoms of zeolites to a more concentrated state, which may generate more strong acid sites. As a result, more side reactions will take place in the case of vapor-phase benzene alkylation with ethylene. On the other hand, the blocking of pores not only reduces the accessibility of the active sites, but also slows down the diffusion of the product molecules (EB and/or PEB). The activity and stability of the catalyst are consequently reduced [21]. Unfortunately, the effects of binders (the binder problem) were usually neglected in academic studies [19]. Preparation of binder-free zeolite is considered to be a definite solution to solve “the binder problem” and is very interesting to both academic and industrial studies. Binder-free ZSM-5 prepared by dry gel conversion (DGC) was reported by several groups in the last few decades [20,22–29]. According to these studies, it was believed that amorphous precursors can be transformed into ZSM-5 morphology in the presence of seeds and/or organic structure directing agents (OSDA) by DGC. Y. Long et al. reported a binder-free MFI zeolite adsorbent, which possessed Si–O framework intact with high hydrophobicity and was efficient in separation of dichlorobenzene isomers [24]. J. Zhou et al. studied a type of full-crystalline hierarchical monolithic ZSM-5 zeolites and proved that it had better activity and longer lifetime in the methanol-to-hydrocarbon (MTH) reaction than conventional catalysts [20]. Besides, the improvement to selectivity for specific catalytic reactions, e. g. benzene alkylation, is not well investigated for the binder-free zeolites. It is interesting if the binder-free zeolites can reduce the undesired xylene formed in the vapor-phase alkylation of benzene with ethylene. In the present work, a core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst is prepared via kneading and extrusion of ZSM-5 parent powder with a pure silica source, colloidal silica, followed by a vapor-solid phase re-crystallization process. The physical and chemical properties of the as made catalysts are investigated by various characterization methods. For vapor-phase alkylation of benzene with ethylene, the superiorities of core-shell binder-free ZSM-5 as well as the inhibiting effects of the binders are discussed for the purpose of preparing more efficient catalyst for industrial EB production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials In the study, four catalyst samples were prepared for comparison according to various typical preparation schemes. Na-form ZSM-5 powder was supplied by Sinopec Catalyst Company. Na-form ZSM-5 powder was turned to H-form by three consecutive ion exchanges with 0.1 M NH4NO3 aqueous solution and subsequent calcination in air at 823 K for 6 h. The product is denoted as S01. For catalytic testing, it was shaped as 12–20 mesh granules by tableting, crushing and screening, successively. S02 and S03 were shaped extrudates. Na-form ZSM-5 powder was vigorously blended and kneaded with binders. The mixtures were then extruded rapidly into uniform cylinders (ɸ = 2.0 mm). The extrudates were dried at 423 K for 6 h, followed by calcination at 823 K for 5 h. For S02, the binder is pseudo-boehmite (Al2O3·H2O), while it is colloidal silica (SiO2 40%) for S03. The content of binder is 35 wt%. S04 was prepared by a vapor-solid-phase re-crystallization method from S03. In the re-crystallization process, 65 wt% ethylamine aqueous solution was used as structure directing agent (SDA). The shaped S03 extrudates were suspended in a Teflon autoclave and isolated from the ethylamine solution with a pore plate in the middle. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 453 K for 72 h. The re-crystallized sample was washed, dried and calcined at the same conditions with S03. All the calcined samples (S02, S03 and S04) were turned to their H-forms by three consecutive ion exchanges with 0.1 M NH4NO3 aqueous solution and subsequent calcination in air at 823 K for 6 h. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA with the scanning rate of 4°/min. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on an FEI Nova NanoSEM 450 microscope and a JEOL-2010 F electron microscope, respectively. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were gathered on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 porosimeter at 77 K. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution were determined by using the BET and BJH methods. The micropore volume was calculated by t-plot method at a relative pressure (p/p0) ranging from 0.05 to 0.35. The Si/Al molar ratios were determined using chemical elemental analysis, in which inductively coupled plasma (ICP) method was carried out on a Varian 725-ES optical emission spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using a Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD spectrometer with Al Kα radiation as the excitation source. The surface Si/Al ratio of samples was determined by areas of the Si 2p peak at 100.2 eV and the Al 2p peak at 74.7 eV. NH3-TPD (temperature programmed desorption) was carried out from 373 K to 873 K under helium flow with a heating rate of 10 K/min on a custom built apparatus. The desorbed ammonia was measured by GC equipped with a TCD (thermal conductivity detector). The acidity amount of each peak area was determined by absorption of the desorbed ammonia with hydrochloric acid followed by a back titration with sodium hydroxide. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra of adsorbed pyridine were recorded on a Nicolet Nexus 470 FT-IR spectrometer furnished with an in situ sample cell. The spectra were recorded after pyridine adsorption at room temperature and evacuation at a desired temperature (473–673 K). 29Si magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) measurements were performed on a Varian-400WB spectrometer, which was obtained at 79.4 MHz using 4-mm MAS probe with a spinning rate of 10 kHz. Chemical shifts were referenced to tetramethylsilane (TMS). 2.3 Catalytic performance test The vapor-phase benzene alkylation with ethylene was performed in a stainless fixed bed reactor with an inner diameter of 12 mm. Samples were loaded and pretreated at 723 K for 2 h under N2 flow before reaction. Benzene was pumped in and evaporated to maintain a stable vapor flow, before ethylene was added into the reactor by a gas mass flowmeter. The products were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7890B) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). Ethylene conversion, product selectivity were calculated by the formulas below according to the GC analyzing results. Ethylene conversion (%) = (Xethylene after reaction – Xethylene before reaction) / Xethylene before reaction × 100% Selectivity to EB and DEB (total ethylation selectivity) (%) = (XEB+XDEB) / Xbenzene reacted × 100% Selectivity to EB (%) = XEB / Xbenzene reacted × 100% Distribution of selectivity to m-DEB (%) = Xm-DEB / (Xm-DEB + Xp-DEB + Xo-DEB) × 100% Distribution of selectivity to p-DEB (%) = Xp-DEB / (Xm-DEB + Xp-DEB + Xo-DEB) × 100% Distribution of selectivity to o-DEB (%) = Xo-DEB / (Xm-DEB + Xp-DEB + Xo-DEB) × 100% Index of xylene (10−6) = Xxylene/XEB × 106 X is representative to mass percentage of each component. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Formation of binder-free zeolitic structure XRD patterns of the samples are listed in Fig. 1 . All the patterns of the four samples show characteristic peaks of ZSM-5 zeolite (MFI topology). In the presence of binders, characteristic peaks of S02 and S03 exhibit less intensity than that of S01, the unshaped ZSM-5 sample. We can compare these samples by relative crystallinity, which is calculated by the area sum of the six strongest diffraction peaks in XRD patterns. The relative crystallinity of S01 is defined to be 100%, while it is 65%, 67% and 105% for S02, S03 and S04, respectively. S04, the re-crystallization product of S03, is found to have an obviously higher relative crystallinity its precursor, which indicates that the silica binder in S03 can be transformed into MFI-type zeolite phase via hydrothermal re-crystallization in the presence of ethylamine. Photos captured by SEM and TEM are shown in Figs. 2 and 3 . According to the SEM and TEM photos, the samples S02 and S03 show obvious two separated phase (zeolite phase and binder phase). For S02 the zeolite crystal is found to be covered by a shell of small bar-type crystals with the size of 5˜10 nm, which is correlated with gamma-alumina. For S03, the situation is quite similar with that of S02. The covering amorphous silica shell is small spheres with the size of about 20 nm. On the other hand, the samples S01 and S04 show uniform zeolite phase. The crystal size of S04 is in the range of 200˜300 nm, which is slightly larger than that of S01. The crystal shape of S01 is quasi-sphere. It indicates that S01 is composed of numerous small poly-crystals of ZSM-5. Compared to S01, the shape of S04 is observed to be typically hexagonal. Comparing S03 to S04, it is found that the amorphous silica shell (S03) disappears and transforms to a zeolitic shell (S04) after re-crystallization in the presence of ethylamine. It can also be explained why the crystal of S04 is larger and more regular than that of S01, the original zeolite powder. It can be concluded that the zeolite crystals and other amorphous species are rearranged via re-crystallization. The bulk and surface Si/Al molar ratio are determined by ICP-AES and XPS, respectively. The results are listed in Table 1 . Because S02 is made of ZSM-5 and alumina binder, the measurement of Si/Al ratio for S02 is meaningless. The bulk Si/Al molar ratios of S03 and S04 are higher than that of S01, due to the addition of colloidal silica. It can be observed that the bulk Si/Al molar ratio of the sample do not change before and after re-crystallization (S03 and S04). But the surface Si/Al molar ratios are obviously lower than the bulk values, which indicates the enrichment of Al atoms on the crystal surface during crystallization of ZSM-5 zeolites [30]. In the same way, the surface Si/Al molar ratio of S04 is found to be a little lower than that of S03. It is observed that a part of Al atoms migrated from the inner channel system to the external surface during the re-crystallization process. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the four samples are shown in Fig. 4 . The isotherms of S02 and S03 are observed to be a combination of Type I and Type IV with H1 a hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of meso-pores supplied by silica or alumina binders. The figures of pore distribution (2˜100 nm) of S02 and S03 show that the meso-pore volumes are mainly located at the pore size areas of 2 nm and 10 nm which were contributed to MFI zeolites and the binders, respectively. BET surface area, micro-pore surface area and micro-pore volume are dramatically reduced in the presence of binders. The micro-porosity of ZSM-5 is negatively influenced by the silica or alumina binders. On the other hand, the isotherms of S01 and S04 are both Type I, indicating their MFI framework with micro-porosity and limited meso-porosity. The meso-pore volumes are only located at the pore size areas of 2 nm, which indicates their pure zeolite composition. It is remarkable that the difference of nitrogen ad-/desorption phenomena between S03 and S04 is big enough, despite the similar chemical composition. The mechanical strength of S04 is higher than that of S03, which indicates a stronger chemical bonding is formed by re-crystallization. It is the other evidence that proves the success of re-crystallization. It is important to point out that the sample S01 (12–20 mesh) does not have enough mechanical strength to meet the requirement of industrial application. 29Si MAS NMR spectra of the four samples are investigated, in which various Si species can be accurately pointed out by the peaks with different chemical shift values [31]. According to the four spectra in Fig. 5 , most of the Si species are Si-(O-Si)4 (−114 ppm) type due to the relatively high Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5 parent powder. A small part of Si-(O-Si)3 is also found at about -100 ppm for all the samples. For the sample containing alumina binder (S02), an obvious peak is found at about -95 ppm referring to the interaction between Si species and the alumina binder. S03 can be regarded as the mechanical mixture of ZSM-5 and amorphous silica binder, and a part of Si atoms are supplied by the silica binder. As a result, a lower condensation characteristic of the HO–Si bond is observed by the spectrum of 29Si MAS NMR at -85 to -105 ppm. The spectrum of the re-crystallized sample (S04) is quite different from that of its precursor (S03) but is similar with that of the ZSM-5 parent powder (S01). Trace amount of lower condensation Si species are detected for S01 and S04 indicating their high condensation characteristic of HO–Si bond. 3.2 Acidity measurement The acidity properties of the four samples are measured by NH3-TPD, and the results are summarized in Table 2 . For each measured sample, there are two evident peaks corresponding to weak and medium-strong acid sites, respectively. For S01, S03 and S04, the peak of weak acid sites is located at about 513 K, and for S02, 537 K, due to the contribution of alumina binder. Moreover, the amount of weak acid sites (393˜623 K) of S02 is larger than other three samples. On the other hand, medium-strong acid sites (623˜873 K) are commonly considered to be the supplier of the active sites for catalytic reactions. They are always generated by defects of zeolites and correlated to the framework Al atoms. According to the NH3-TPD results, the amounts of the four studied samples are nearly equal. However, the peak temperature values are different. For the binder-containing samples, S02 and S03, the peak of medium-strong acid sites is located at 731 K, which is obviously higher than that of the binder-free samples, S01 (718 K) and S04 (717 K). It indicated that the acidities of S02 and S03 are stronger than that of S03 and S04. Pyridine adsorbed FTIR is another efficient method to measure the acidity properties of the four samples. As shown in Fig. 6 , both Brønsted (1540 cm−1) and Lewis (1450 cm−1) acid sites are observed on the samples. Quantified into the integrated areas of the peaks at 1540 and 1450 cm−1, the amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites are compared at various pyridine desorption temperature to reveal the acidity properties of the samples. Pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites is much easier to be desorbed than that adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites, indicating the weakness of Lewis acid sites. It is believed that Brønsted acid sites plays an important role in benzene alkylation with ethylene. According to Fig. 6, desorption of pyridine from the Brønsted acid sites of S02 and S03 is more difficult than that of S01 and S04, when temperature is raised. It is to say that the Brønsted acidities of S02 and S03 are stronger. The results are in agreement with that of NH3-TPD. Consequently, looking back to the previous characterization results, it can be concluded that re-crystallization can bring about two obvious advantages for practical zeolite catalysts. Firstly, a shaped catalyst of pure crystallized ZSM-5 morphology can be prepared, which does not contain any amorphous binders. The dilution effects and inhibition to the zeolitic micro-porosity can be avoided in the absence of binders. Secondly, the acidity of the prepared catalyst can be weakened due to the migration of framework Al atoms to surface. 3.3 Catalytic performance in benzene alkylation with ethylene ZSM-5 (MFI type) is used in vapor phase benzene alkylation with ethylene in industrial process of EB manufacturing. Under the typical conditions of industrial EB units, ethylene conversion is always higher than 99% on qualified catalysts. However, selectivity and especially the formation of the key impurity, xylene, are receiving more attentions for practical use of catalysts. Selectivity in benzene alkylation with ethylene can be expressed as the selectivity to total alkylated products (EB + PEBs) and the selectivity to mono-alkylated product (only EB). Besides, xylene is another important index to measure the selectivity. In this paper, the catalytic performance of the four aforementioned samples are tested in vapor phase benzene alkylation with ethylene. Table 3 lists the product distribution results of the four tested samples under the quasi-industrial reaction conditions, in which the ethylene conversions for the all the samples are almost complete. However, the selectivities of the samples differ from each other. According to Table 3, xylene, toluene, C9˜C10 and the heavier formed on S01 and S04 are obviously lower than that formed on S02 and S03. It can also be observed that less diethylbenzene (DEB) is formed on S01 and S04, indicating a higher EB selectivity than S02 and S03. On one hand, the enhancement of selectivity on binder-free samples (S01 and S04) can be attributed to the reduction of acidity caused by the inexistence of binders, which can decelerate side reactions, such as EB isomerization. On the other hand, the interference of amorphous binders can be avoided, and the target product EB can be desorbed more easily from the active sites. DEB is an exceptive by-product, which is formed by consecutive alkylation with ethylene and can be used to recover EB via trans-alkylation with benzene. There are three isomers in the alkylation mixture, m-DEB (d ≈ 7.2 Å), p-DEB (d ≈ 4.3 Å) and o-DEB (d ≈ 7.8 Å), in which p-DEB is the smallest one in size. Because the size of p-DEB is compatible with the channel size of ZSM-5 (5.5 Å), p-DEB has the most probability to be formed inside the channels of ZSM-5. However, fast isomerization takes place on the external surface of the zeolite crystals and affects the shape selectivity. Therefore, p-DEB is converted, and a DEB isomer mixture is obtained with a composition of quasi-thermodynamic equilibrium (m-:p-:o-DEB ≈ 60:35:5). When the surface acidity of zeolites is annihilated by coking, silanization or modification with oxides, the p-DEB selectivity will be raised [32–36]. In the present work, shape selectivity of the four samples are investigated. The shape selectivity of S01 is close to thermodynamic equilibrium values. For the extruded samples, the external surface is covered by particles of alumina (S02) or silica (S03) binders according to the SEM and TEM photos, and the p-DEB selectivity is raised. Compared with S02, S03 has a more densified silica shell. As a result, it has the highest p-DEB selectivity. As mentioned before, a part of Al atoms migrate from the inner channel system to the external surface after re-crystallization, and the surface acidity is enhanced. It is why the p-DEB selectivity reduced slightly for the re-crystallized sample (S04). The catalytic performance affected by reaction temperature is comparatively investigated for S02 (conventional catalyst) and S04 (binder free catalyst). It should be pointed out that S02 (ZSM-5 + alumina) is a conventional scheme of catalyst preparation that catalyze vapor-phase benzene alkylation with ethylene in industry. It is why it is chosen as the opponent against S04 (the binder free catalyst). According to the results in Fig. 7 , the ethylene conversion decreases with the decreasing of temperature. For both S02 and S04, the ethylene conversion is nearly complete when the temperature is above 633 K. Both the selectivity to (EB + DEB) and to EB are enhanced with the increasing temperature. The by-products, such as propyl-benzene, butyl-benzene, DEBs, Di-phenyl-ethane, etc., have a tendency to be decomposed or trans-alkylated in an elevated temperatures. However, the formation of xylene is from isomerization of EB, which can be accelerated by the increasing of temperature. As a result, more amount of xylene is formed when the temperature is raised. The m-/p-DEB ratio is also raised with the increasing temperature, because the isomerization of DEB isomers on the external surface of catalysts is accelerated. In order to evaluate the stability, aging experiments of the samples are carried out under a reaction condition with lower B/E ratio and higher GHSV, which can accelerated coking on the catalysts. The EB yield versus time on stream curves are shown in Fig. 8 . The stability of the samples is in the sequence below: S04 > S02 > S03. It is found that the coking amount of the reacted samples after 100 h is measured by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). The value of S04 (11.6%) is lower than that of S02 (14.9%) and S03 (15.8%). S03 possesses the worst stability due to its densified silica shell and lowest specific surface area (BET). The enhancement of the stability of S04 refers to weakened acidity, larger specific surface area and more microporous composition supplied by ZSM-5. Firstly, weakened acidity can decelerate side reactions. Moreover, larger specific surface area and more microporous composition allow the catalyst to accommodate more amounts of coke formed in the reaction. The 2000-hour-lifetime tests of S02 and S04 are carried out under typical conditions of industrial EB units. According to the results in Fig. 9 , the xylene/EB value on the conventional catalyst (S02) is at about 1150 ppm, and a slight deactivation is also detected on it. Compared with the results of S02, no obvious deactivation is found during the period of reaction on the binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst (S04), and the xylene/EB value is constantly at about 600 ppm. It indicates a good catalytic performance for the binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst in the practical use in industrial production of EB. Looking back to the preparation method of Shaped Core-Shell Structured Binder-free ZSM-5 Catalyst (S04), it is important to point out that the recipe and preparation process do not need to be changed when it is prepared in a ton-scale re-crystallization batch. It is to say that this method is very easy to be realized in large-scale industrial catalyst manufacturing. The SDA, ethylamine aqueous solution, which can be recycled easily, does the least damage to the environment. The mechanical strength of the binder-free catalyst is high enough to meet the requirement of the fixed bed catalytic reaction of vapor-phase benzene alkylation with ethylene. 4 Conclusion In summary, a kind of shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst is prepared by re-crystallization method from a shaped mixture of ZSM-5 and amorphous silica binder. The different catalyst samples are prepared by various methods, with or without binders. The negative effects of alumina or silica binders on catalyst properties are revealed by XRD, TEM, 29Si MAS NMR, Py- FTIR, etc. It is found that the silica shell surrounding the ZSM-5 core in the shaped mixture can be converted into ZSM-5 phase under the vapor-solid phase hydrothermal conditions. A core-shell zeolite structure is consequently formed. As a result, the prepared binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst has much amount of zeolitic micro-pores, and the acidity is reduced due to the migration of framework aluminum towards outer shell layers of ZSM-5 crystals. The catalytic performance in vapor-phase benzene alkylation with ethylene is investigated. It is not only influenced by reaction conditions, but also by the porosity and acidic properties of the prepared catalysts. The shaped binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst shows an enhanced stability and selectivity compared to the conventional binder-containing catalyst due to its increased micro-pores and weakened acidity, over which less xylene is formed. In view of its good mechanical strength, as well as its extended lifetime, the shaped binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst can be valuable in the practical industrial ethylbenzene production. Acknowledgements The authors wish to acknowledge the funding support of this work by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (91534115) and the National Key Research and Development Project (2016YFC1102300). coredata.dc:description: A kind of shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst is prepared by re-crystallization method, from a shaped mixture of ZSM-5 zeolite and pure silica source as a binder. According to the characterization results, it is found that the silica shell, surrounding the ZSM-5 core in the shaped mixture, can be converted into ZSM-5 zeolite phase under the hydrothermal conditions with vapor-solid phase method. In this way, the catalyst with core-shell zeolite structure is consequently formed. The prepared binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst has more micro-pores than the ordinary shaped zeolite with a binder. In addition, its acidity is weakened because of the migration of framework aluminum towards the outer shell layer of ZSM-5 crystals. When applied to the vapor-phase benzene alkylation with ethylene, this catalyst shows an enhanced stability and selectivity compared to the ordinary shaped catalyst. Specially, xylene, a critical by-product formed by side reactions, is greatly suppressed over the shaped core-shell structured binder-free catalyst. In view of its good mechanical strength as well as its extended lifetime, the shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst will be valuable in the practical industrial ethylbenzene production.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of a shaped core-shell structured binder-free ZSM-5 catalyst and its application for benzene alkylation with ethylene
